|Title=Knowing the definition of maternal-fetal infection (MFI)
|Description=None
|Rubric=Definition
|Contributors=Alexandre Vivanti, Philippe Deruelle
|Order=1}}
Maternal-foetal infection is the result of contamination of the foetus during pregnancy or delivery by germs of maternal origin. It is also called early bacterial neonatal infection if bacterial.

Depending on the agent responsible and the stage of the pregnancy, MFIs can lead to :

- Miscarriages

- Embryopathies

- Foetal infections = foetopathies

- In utero or neonatal death

- Post-natal infections which may be symptomatic from the 1st day, or at a later date

question.title: What are the possible consequences of maternal-fetal infection (MFI) during pregnancy or delivery?

option_a.title: Only miscarriages and embryopathies
option_a.description: This option is partially correct, but does not include all possible consequences

option_b.title: Only foetal infections and in utero or neonatal death
option_b.description: This option is partially correct, but does not include miscarriages, embryopathies, and post-natal infections

option_c.title: All of the above: miscarriages, embryopathies, foetal infections, in utero or neonatal death, and post-natal infections

option_d.title: Only post-natal infections
option_d.description: This option is incorrect, as it does not include other possible consequences of MFI
